title: Are there any generic heads-up displays (HUD) that may display any input? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are many of them for exampe at amazon.com. What they have in common is that they use the OBD2 interface, most of them with a wired connection, so you’ll need to run a wire from the HUD module which will sit atop your dashboard facing the windshield (and reflecting the data on some sticky film you’ll have to put there), to the HUD port in your car which will usually be somewhere below the steering column on the driver’s side. What they display is usually the most generic info and it’s fixed (80’s type LCD screens with fixed characters/graphics, it can enough for this kind of use but won’t leave you too much freedom for customization). Or you can go a more DIY route: you get an OBD2 wireless dongleget a small android tablet / use your android phone with torque PRO applicationSet it in HUD modeBuy a film you can paste on your windshield so the images can reflectThis one is a pretty customizable solution, I’ve used torque pro in the past and it’s just great (not as HUD but rather hanging the phone somewhere not obstructive so I could look at it directly). In this way you won’t need to run a wire to the OBD2 port but you will need one to provide current to the device. For short enough trips you can make do with just charging it before going out, though. I’d rather use the second option because it’s so easy to customize Torque pro and there are already some very neat interfaces you can get from the playstore (like racing meter for torque pro)

A new product just appeared on the market - Hudly (http://gethudly.com). It is designed as a HUD that mirrors the screen of your smartphone, but it actually has a full size HDMI input, so you can connect any video source. Please note that the projector’s resolution is 480x240, but it’s more than enough for a HUD.
Yes there are some HUD displays that allow connectivity through a VGA or HDMI port. Check this out -Laser Scanning FW-HUD I hope this would be helpful.
